Alessandro,

Multiphase equilibrium is not currently implemented.  But you can do it  
yourself. For example, suppose you want to allow solid silicon, You  
need to know some thermodynamic data for solid silicon, so that you can  
compute its Gibbs function. This is available from many sources,  
including the NIST Chemistry WebBook.

Now create a Si-C-H gas mixture with the species you want to consider.  
Pick an overall Si/C/H elemental ratio, and pick some fraction of the  
silicon to be  in the solid phase. Initialize the gas composition so  
that it contains the rest of the silicon, plus all of the carbon and  
hydrogen. It doesn't matter which species you choose for the initial  
composition; only the elemental composition matters. Set the gas to  
equilibrium holding (T,P) fixed.

Now compute the total Gibbs function at the desired (T,P):   G(T,P)  =  
(solid_Si_mass) x g(Si)  +  (gas_mass) x g(gas).  Adjust the mass of  
the solid Si, recomputing the gas composition each time and setting it  
to equilibrium, until G reaches a minimum.

You can do the same process considering SiC or C as the condensed phase,

You can also quickly map out the regions of the ternary phase diagram  
where solid phases will first precipitate out. For this purpose, it is  
convenient to include atomic Si and atomic C in the vapor. Compute the  
gas-only equilibrium composition, and examine the chemical potentials  
of Si and C in the vapor. Solid Si will appear where the vapor Si  
chemical potential = the Gibbs function for the solid. Same idea for C.  
For SiC, the solid will precipitate where the silicon carbide Gibbs  
function = the sum of the Si and C vapor chemical potentials. The  
region where the vapor species chemical potentials are lower than all  
possible solids is the region where no precipitates exist.

Dave G.


On Tuesday, July 22, 2003, at 03:18 AM, Alessandro wrote:

> Dear Professor Goodwin,
> I am a PhD student and I would like to study the multiphase
> thermodynamic
> equilibrium of a Si-H-C system.
> I have already studied the gas phase equlibrium of the same system
> with
> Cantera.
> I would like to know if it is possible study it with the Cantera code.
> Where can I find an example or the documentation about the multiphase
> equilibrium?
>
> Thanks
> Alessandro Veneroni
